ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LATE SENATOR BENIGNO AQUINO
(Information on Movements)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture whether the Singapore government gave any information to the Government of the Philippines or its Army about the movements of the late Senator Benigno Aquino before his arrival in Manila and, if so, what information was given.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, on 19th August 1983, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs informed the Philippine Embassy that it had information that the late Senator Benigno Aquino had arrived in Singapore on 16th August and had already left on the morning of 19th August by Pan-Am bound for Hong Kong, San Francisco and Los Angeles.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, as I understand the Minister to say the Ministry of Foreign Affairs had informed the Philippines Government, may I ask whether the Philippines Government or any agency made a request for his information and for his movements to be monitored?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, nobody asked us but at that time there was considerable speculation as to when and how Senator Aquino would get into Manila. Since the Philippines is a friendly country, information about the arrival and departure of Aquino was passed on to the Philippine Embassy as normal diplomatic courtesy.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister not realise that his answer does not really reveal anything? He is getting clever at this game. Would the Minister say what was the reason? Does the Ministry of Foreign Affairs pass on information to other governments every time one of their nationals passes through Singapore?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid I cannot explain to the Member in anything other than simple English. I

Column: 2120

thought I was quite clear. I said we were not asked, and I gave the reason why we gave the information - that it was normal courtesy, since the Philippines is a friendly country, to provide such information in the light of the fact that there was considerable speculation about his arrival in Manila.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member is pursuing a line where he is implying that there was something nefarious to what we have done. If so, he should state so.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am here to ask questions, not to answer questions. It is for the Ministers to answer questions here. Now, the Minister keeps saying "in the light", but what was compelling in this "light" that made it necessary for the Singapore Government to give this information?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I find it difficult to explain in any simpler language than what I have said. I have already explained very clearly why and what the circumstances were that led us to giving this information. He says his job is to ask questions. I am quite aware, Sir. One fool can ask more questions than a thousand wisemen can answer. But what is his line? He is trying to imply that there was something underhand about this information that we provided. If that is what he is implying, why does he not say so? I have got an answer to that.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister answer the question, Is it the usual rule for his Ministry to supply information to governments every time a national of the country passes through Singapore? I asked that question and he has not answered that question.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, this is really getting us nowhere.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: No, it isn't.

     Mr Dhanabalan: I have stated clearly what the circumstances were. Surely, circumstances will vary from time to time.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: What were the circumstances?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sorry. We are not here to educate the

Column: 2121

Member for Anson. If he does not read the newspapers, he is not aware of what was happening in Manila. I think he was not aware because he has never shown any interest in events in the Philippines until he read a report in the Straits Times on the 13th of October, which was based on a draft report and which referred to the information that we had provided the Philippine Embassy here, The very next day, without waiting, he rushed to the nearest phone, I think, and telephoned in a statement saying that he intended to raise this question of the Government. He never showed any interest in the Philippines before, and if he does not know what the circumstances were in the Philippines before Aquino arrived in Manila, then I am afraid this House is not the place where he is going to be educated. He should go and read the newspapers for himself.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Minister really so obtuse that he does not understand questions directed at him?

     The Second Deputy Prime Minister (Foreign Affairs) (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Obtuse questions will obtain obtuse answers.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, we are not talking about the circumstances in the Philippines. What I want to know is what were the circumstances that prompted Singapore to supply this information? Secondly, may I know why his Ministry declined to comment on this when they were asked on the 14th whether this was true? Why conceal it?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not going to answer his first question because I have repeated more than once what the circumstances were. As to his second question, unlike the Member for Anson, the Ministry does not comment on newspaper reports based on reporters' speculations on drafts which were leaked in Manila. The official report was not out until the 24th of October. It was true. Has the Member read the Agrava Report? May I ask him - have you read the Agrava Report?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: If it was true, why decline comment?

Column: 2122



     Mr Speaker: Let us go to the second Question. Mr Jeyaretnam.

Column: 2122

KEPPEL SHIPYARD
(Acquisition of Straits Steamship shares)


    2. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry whether he will make a statement on the acquisition by the Government company, Keppel Shipyard, of the shares in Straits Steamship.

     The Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have no statement to make on a purely commercial transaction which has already been fully reported in the press.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister not realise that he has a duty in this, Keppel being a company in which the public are interested, their monies invested in it, it is a government-owned company. Does the Minister really think that he can get away without making any statement?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the acquisition by Keppel Shipyard of the shares in Straits Steamship was, as I have said, a commercial transaction which was done by a publicly-listed company taking over another publicly-listed company, and as such I see no need to make a statement.

Column: 2122

IMMIGRATION (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.
2.40 pm

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, although Singapore is a small country, we have attracted visitors from all over the world. Last year, 2.5 million foreigners visited Singapore from countries other than Malaysia. In addition, we have more than 150,000 foreign workers in Singapore on work permit. While we welcome the bona fide tourists and those who are legally working here, there are also a number of foreigners who have abused our hospitality and flouted our laws. The number of foreigners who were convicted for immigration offences in

Column: 2123

Singapore increased from 584 in 1981 to 1,207 in 1982 and 1,225 in 1983. The corresponding figure for the first nine months of this year was 1,553. In addition, many foreigners have also committed criminal offences in Singapore. From 1981 to 1983, a total of 7,565 foreigners were arrested for committing various criminal offences. The number of foreigners who come and commit crime in Singapore is rising.

    The present penalties in the Immigration Act are not sufficient to deter foreigners who intend to break our laws, or to effectively discourage people from harbouring or employing such foreigners. It is therefore necessary to amend the Immigration Act to provide for deterrent penalties for certain offences such as those relating to illegal entry, contravention of a Prohibition of Entry Order, illegal overstaying and harbouring or employing any person who has contravened our immigration laws.

    Clause 2 of the Bill seeks to enhance the penalty for illegal entry into Singapore. Offenders will be liable to imprisonment for a term not less than six months and not exceeding two years, and a fine not exceeding $6,000. It is necessary to prescribe a heavier penalty for this offence, as foreigners who resort to entering our country illegally are a threat to our society. If they are not caught and penalised, they will remain here illegally for a long time and also commit crime. We cannot afford to allow such illegal immigrants to sink their roots here and be a severe burden on our housing, social, educational, health services at the expense of our citizens. We must therefore take tough measures to discourage foreigners from coming in and remaining here illegally. The present penalty which is imprisonment for a term not exceeding one year or a fine not exceeding $4,000 or both, is not a sufficient deterrent. The number of persons prosecuted for this offence had risen from 79 in 1982 to 95 in 1983.

    Clause 3 increases the penalty for the contravention of a Prohibition & Entry Order to include imprisonment for a term not less than two years and not more than

Column: 2124

four years, and a fine not exceeding $6,000. The penalty is further enhanced in cases where the offender had previously committed any offence punishable with not less than three years imprisonment and who enters Singapore by using a travel document bearing a different name from that stated in the Order made against him. In such a case, he will be liable to imprisonment for a term of two years to five years and a fine not exceeding $10,000, and also to caning. This amendment to the law is necessary because the contravention of a Prohibition of Entry Order is one of the most serious offences under the Immigration Act. A Prohibition of Entry Order is only issued on foreigners who have committed serious offences in Singapore and they have to be kept out. Since 1978, a total of 83 persons who were issued with Prohibition of Entry Orders had re-entered Singapore illegally, Out of this figure, 46 were found to have commiffed further offences after their illegal entry into Singapore. The present penalty of imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months or a fine not exceeding $2,000 or both such imprisonment and fine, is again manifestly inadequate. From January 1983 to September this year, 34 foreigners were convicted for contravening the Prohibition of Entry Order issued against them. Out of the 34 foreigners, 16 of them came in with new passports bearing different names. It is therefore necessary to impose a higher penalty, including caning, on foreign criminals who not only contravene Prohibition of Entry Orders, but also for their criminal deception. Such foreigners are obviously here to commit crime. They pose a danger to the security of our country, and we should not permit them to get away lightly when they are apprehended. Most of the offenders in the past were only fined between $400 and $2,000.

    The Bill also provides for enhanced penalties for overstaying in Singapore. Our liberal entry policy allows nationals of most countries in the world to visit Singapore without a visa. While we welcome the genuine visitors, we are also faced with a large number of foreigners who are reluctant to leave when their Social Visit Passes expire. Some who have come here from countries which are less well off than

Column: 2125

Singapore are tempted to stay on and work illegally. There are also cases of foreign workers who have resisted repatriation upon the expiry or cancellation of their work permits. If we do not discourage such foreigners from overstaying in Singapore illegally, there could be grave social repercussions for the country in the long term. Since they do not have a steady income from legal employment, some may resort to crime.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is necessary to ensure that our laws do not make it worthwhile for foreigners to prolong their stay in Singapore without a valid Immigration Pass. Under clause 4, if the period of overstay does not exceed 90 days, the penalty will be imprisonment not exceeding six months or a fine not exceeding $4,000 or both such imprisonment and fine. This is similar to the existing penalty except that the maximum fine has been increased from $2,000 to $4,000. If the period of overstay is more than 90 days, the offender will be liable to imprisonment for a term of not less than six months and not exceeding two years, and a fine not exceeding $6,000. Foreigners who overstay for such a long period often do so wilfully and are likely to be working here illegally. Some may have no intention of going back at all if they are not caught and may even start to have families in Singapore if they stay here long enough. Perhaps they hope that by prolonging their stay here for a long time, they could eventually pass off as Singaporeans and make Singapore their permanent home. This will be most undesirable and is detrimental to the interest of our citizens.

    As Singapore is only a small country of 618.1 sq km with a very high population density, we can ill-afford to accommodate such foreigners, especially when most of them have no skills and cannot make any economic contribution to our country. A heavier penalty is therefore prescribed for long term overstayers. The Immigration Department can normally distinguish between those who overstay inadvertently for a few days, and those who do so intentionally without a valid reason. Usually only the bad cases are prosecuted while others are warned or given composition fines. In 1983 the number of over-

Column: 2126

stayers who were warned or given composition fines was 56,199, while the corresponding figure for the first nine months of this year was 55,180. 784 overstayers were prosecuted by the Immigration Department in 1983 compared to 1,382 from January to September this year.

    The Bill also seeks to amend section 36 of the Immigration Act to increase the penalty for the offence of unlawful return after removal. This is a serious offence as it involves foreigners who have been sent out of Singapore for various reasons, but choose to enter again illegally. The number of these cases rose sharply to 166 in 1983 compared to 39 in 1982 and only three in 1981. The present penalty of imprisonment not exceeding two years or a fine not exceeding $4,000 or both such imprisonment and fine is grossly inadequate. The proposed penalty will now include mandatory imprisonment for a term of not less than one year and not exceeding three years, and a fine not exceeding $6,000. The penalty for attempted unlawful entry will be imprisonment for a term not less than three months and not exceeding two years, and a fine not exceeding $4,000.

    The present penalty for abetting any person to enter or leave Singapore in contravention of the Immigration Act or Regulations is imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or a fine not exceeding $6,000 or both such imprisonment and fine. The penalty for this offence will be enhanced to include mandatory imprisonment for a term not less than six months and not exceeding two years. Twelve persons were convicted for this offence in 1983 compared to four each in 1982 and 1981.

    In addition, the Bill seeks to enhance the penalty for harbouring or employing any person who has contravened the Immigration Act or Regulations. The existing penalty for these offences is imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or a fine not exceeding $6,000 or both such imprisonment and fine. The penalty will now be enhanced to include mandatory imprisonment for a term not less than six months and not exceeding two years, so as to deter would-be offenders. Furthermore, a person who gives shelter to an

Column: 2127

overstayer of more than 90 days or an illegal immigrant, would be presumed, until the contrary is proved, to know that the person whom he has harboured is an illegal overstayer or an illegal immigrant. Mr Speaker, Sir, it is important to stress the seriousness of the offence because these people who are willing to offer shelter for the illegal overstayers or immigrants are in fact encouraging more foreigners to remain in Singapore illegally. They are the main source of the problem. The penalty for these offences must therefore be sufficiently deterrent so that it will not be worthwhile for anyone to harbour or employ any person who has contravened our immigration laws. The number of persons apprehended for the offence of harbouring increased sharply to 166 in 1983 compared to 57 in 1982 and 39 in 1981. Fifty-three persons were convicted of the offence of employing illegal overstayers or illegal immigrants in 1983 while 39 were convicted of the same offence during the first nine months of this year.

    Finally, the Bill also seeks to increase the maximum amount for compounding offences under the Immigration Act and Regulations from $100 to $500.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - (Mr Chua Sian Chin),

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 2127

PENSIONS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.
2.59 pm

     The Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, 'That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    At present, the eligible dependants of a pensionable officer are granted a death gratuity in the event of his death. The death gratuity amounts to:

Column: 2128



    (i) one year's last-drawn salary; or

    (ii) the commuted pension gratuity, if this is greater.

    The commuted pension gratuity is equivalent to the retirement gratuity the officer would have received had he retired instead on the date of his death.

    The Government feels that the quantum of death gratuity for pensionable officers needs to be enhanced in view of the current difference in the rate of employer's CPF contribution between pensionable and non-pensionable officers. The employer's rate of CPF contribution for pensionable officers is 15% whereas it is 25% for non-pensionable officers. At least for death benefits there should be some parity between pensionable and non-pensionable officers. It is thus proposed to pay to the dependants of a pensionable officer who dies in harness a gratuity based on 10% of his last-drawn monthly salary for each month of service, as 10% is the current difference in the employer's rate of CPF contribution between the pensionable and non-pensionable officers. For convenience, the proposed method of computing gratuity will be referred to as the "10% formula". The gratuity shall be subject to a maximum of three years' salary. It shall also, as at present, be no less than one year's salary.

    Clause 2 of the Pensions (Amendment) Bill, 1984, provides for the death gratuity to be computed as proposed. Pension benefits computed based on the 10% formula amount to 1/10 of one month's salary for each complete month of service. However, in the Pensions Act pension benefits are reckoned in terms of annual and not monthly pensionable emoluments. Hence in the Bill the 10% formula has to be expressed as "1/120 of one year's pensionable emoluments" for each complete month of service.

    Sir, I take this opportunity to inform the House of a consequential amendment to the -retirement gratuity. If improvement is made only to the death gratuity, there will be the anomaly of a person being worth more when he is dead than when he is alive since the proposed death gratuity based on the 10% formula will always be

Column: 2129

greater than the commuted pension gratuity, which is the retirement gratuity. To rectify the anomaly, the retirement gratuity should also be based on the 10% formula. The Pensions Regulations, 1956, will therefore be amended accordingly.

    The retirement gratuity is, in fact, an advance against future monthly pension. At present, this gratuity is a lump sum payment equivalent to one-quarter of full pension for 12 1/2 years. The monthly pension is accordingly reduced to three-quarters of full pension for the first 12 1/2 years after retirement. After 12 1/2 years full pension will be paid. If the retirement gratuity is now enhanced by the 10% formula, the monthly pension for the first 12 1/2 years after retirement will consequently be reduced because of the increase in the sum advanced.

    The amendment to the Pensions Regulaions, 1956, will take effect on the same date as the Pensions (Amendment) Bill, 1984.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder whether the 13th month payment is taken into account in his computation? It does not appear to be so. Therefore, there appears to be a slight discrepancy because the officer on CPF would have been paid 25% of this 13th month payment into his CPF as well.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, there is no discrepancy. The 13th month payment is not pensionable.

     Dr Augustine Tan: I know it is not pensionable. But if the object is to make it equivalent to the CPF contributor, then it should be incorporated for this purpose.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the object is to enhance the rate of death gratuity in the event of a civil servant dying in harness. The object is not to make a strict equivalence.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam].

Column: 2130



    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 2130

ECONOMIC EXPANSION INCENTIVES (RELIEF FROM INCOME TAX)

(AMENDMENT NO. 2) BILL



    Order for Second Reading read.
3.05 pm

     The Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Bill proposes to amend the Economic Expansion Incentives (Relief from Income Tax) Act to effect the investment allowance scheme announced in the 1984 Budget Statement, to encourage local companies to invest in new technology projects.

    Sir, many of the established local companies have accumulated substantial reserves through investing in traditional industries. With rising wages and increasingly stiff international competition, the local companies will have to diversify into new industries and services to maintain their growth. Some have already done so. For instance, National Iron and Steel Mills and Wearnes Brothers have gone into computer equipment; Fraser and Neave into using biotechnology methods to cultivate mushrooms; and ACMA into personal computers, However, these are few and far between.

    New technology industries are inherently more risky. Incentives must therefore be given to encourage our local investors to venture into new frontiers of technological advancement and help to broaden our technological base.

    The Bill creates a new Part, Part VID on "Investments in New Technology Companies" to deal with the incentive scheme for investments in new technology companies. Under the proposed scheme, a local company which invests in an approved new technology project can deduct its share of losses in the project against its other income, subject to a maximum of 50% of its equity investment.

Column: 2131



    A company is defined as a local company if 50% or more of its equity is owned by Singapore citizens or permanent residents.

    The deduction will only be granted if the new project does not make any cumulative profit during the first three years.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, just a couple of points for clarification. As the Bill is presented, there seems to be the assumption that the so-called new technology companies have holding companies or parent companies which own them. What about companies which are new ventures altogether?

TRAINING OF SAF PERSONNEL
(SAFETY MEASURES)


    1. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health whether he is satisfied with the measures being taken by the three Services to ensure the safety of SAF personnel undergoing training, especially flying training.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Safety is always a major concern of the SAF. A good safety record is the product of a well run armed force. Competent commanders must design carefully conceived training programmes, to put troops through difficult missions in a graduated sequence. Demanding exercises must yield training value without endangering soldiers, and stringent monitoring must make sure everything goes as planned. Training safety is the hallmark of professionalism.

    The SAF has undertaken many specific measures to promote safety. Comprehensive training safety regulations are published, so that officers need not depend on experience and memory alone when conducting training. For certain units, such as airbases, and for all units during live firing exercises, safety officers are specifically nominated. They have no other responsibilities than to keep constant watch over the training troops. Their job is to stop any one from being carried away by the excitement of the moment, and doing something unsafe. In addition, the Services have inspectorate teams who monitor training activities, so that the headquarters staff will know quickly if anything is going wrong. If an accident does happen, prompt investigation and swift follow-up action ensure that any shortcomings revealed in our procedures and practices are put right.

    Such measures promote safety, but they cannot guarantee that accidents will never happen. When training for war, men and machines are pushed to the limits of their endurance. While the greatest care must be taken to see that they are not pushed accidentally beyond the limits, this must not be done at the expense of training standards. Realistic training must continue, because inadequately trained troops will suffer needless casualties in war. We cannot water down SAF training.

    These observations apply particularly to flying training and operations. The margins for error are finer, the consequences of mistakes are graver, and the risks are ever present. Yet we cannot stop flying. We must fly, but with competent pilots, in well maintained aircraft.

    Our pilot selection and training procedures are rigorous, and are constantly being improved. Only the best become fighter pilots. After they have been trained, they are required to maintain their skills at a high standard, so that they do not unwittingly hazard their aircraft or their lives in the air.

    Even the best pilots in the world can only fly safely if their aircraft are airworthy. The engine, the avionics, the weapon systems on board an aircraft, all must be conscientiously and meticulously maintained. This is the responsibility of engineers, technicians and ground crew, the large support staff required to put one pilot in the air. We have kept abreast of maintenance practices in other air forces, and have modified our own procedures and inspection routines to make increasingly certain that when an aircraft takes off, it is serviceable.

    MINDEF constantly monitors the accident rates of the various types of RSAF aircraft for indications of possible safety problems. So far, the trends have been reassuring. MINDEF intends to keep it that way.
